column16: description
column17: comments

column16: The user-defined identifier for the isolate, as provided by the laboratory that originally isolated the isolate.
column17: Provide the isolate_ID created by the lab that first isolated the isolate (i.e. the original isolate ID). If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value. If only an alternate isolate ID is known (e.g. the ID from your lab, if your lab did not isolate the isolate from the original sample), make asure to include it in the alternative_isolate_ID field.

column16: An alternative isolate_ID assigned to the isolate by another organization.
column17: If one or more alternative isolate_IDs are available, record them all here, separated by a comma.

column16: The user-defined name for the sample.
column17: Store the collector sample ID. If this number is considered identifiable information, provide an alternative ID. Be sure to store the key that maps between the original and alternative IDs for traceability and follow up if necessary. Every collector sample ID from a single submitter must be unique. It can have any format, but we suggest that you make it concise, unique and consistent within your lab.

column16: The name of the agency that collected the original sample.
column17: The name of the sample collector should be written out in full, (with minor exceptions) and be consistent across multple submissions e.g. Public Health Agency of Canada, Public Health Ontario, BC Centre for Disease Control. The sample collector specified is at the discretion of the data provider (i.e. may be hospital, provincial public health lab, or other).

column16: The name of the project/initiative/program for which the sample was collected.
column17: Provide the name of the project and/or the project ID here. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The email address of the contact responsible for follow-up regarding the sample.
column17: The email address can represent a specific individual or lab e.g. johnnyblogs@lab.ca, or RespLab@lab.ca

column16: The mailing address of the agency submitting the sample.
column17: The mailing address should be in the format: Street number and name, City, Province/Territory, Postal Code, Country
column18: 655 Lab St, Vancouver, British Columbia, V5N 2A2, Canada

column16: The date on which the sample was collected.
column17: Sample collection date is critical for surveillance and many types of analyses. Required granularity includes year, month and day. If this date is considered identifiable information, it is acceptable to add "jitter" by adding or subtracting a calendar day (acceptable by GISAID). Alternatively, ”received date” may be used as a substitute. The date should be provided in ISO 8601 standard format "YYYY-MM-DD".

column16: The date on which the sample was received.
column17: ISO 8601 standard "YYYY-MM-DD".

column16: The country where the sample was collected.
column17: Provide the country name from the controlled vocabulary provided.

column16: The province/territory where the sample was collected.
column17: Provide the province/territory name from the controlled vocabulary provided.

column16: The city where the sample was collected.
column17: Provide the city name. Use this look-up service to identify the standardized term: https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols/ontologies/gaz

column16: The name of a specific geographical location e.g. Credit River (rather than river).
column17: Provide the name of the specific geographical site using a specific noun (a word that names a certain place, thing).

column16: Taxonomic name of the organism.
column17: Use "Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2". This value is provided in the template.

column16: The reason that the sample was collected.
column17: The reason a sample was collected may provide information about potential biases in sampling strategy. Provide the purpose of sampling from the picklist in the template. Most likely, the sample was collected for Diagnostic testing. The reason why a sample was originally collected may differ from the reason why it was selected for sequencing, which should be indicated in the "purpose of sequencing" field.

column16: The description of why the sample was collected, providing specific details.
column17: Provide an expanded description of why the sample was collected using free text. The description may include the importance of the sample for a particular public health investigation/surveillance activity/research question. If details are not available, provide a null value.
column18: The sample was collected to investigate the prevalence of variants associated with mink-to-human transmission in Canada.

column16: The original sample description provided by the sample collector.
column17: Provide the sample description provided by the original sample collector. The original description is useful as it may provide further details, or can be used to clarify higher level classifications.

column16: A substance obtained from an anatomical part of an organism e.g. tissue, blood.
column17: Provide a descriptor if an anatomical material was sampled. Use the picklist provided in the template. If a desired term is missing from the picklist, contact emma_griffiths@sfu.ca. If not applicable, do not leave blank. Choose a null value.

column16: An anatomical part of an organism e.g. oropharynx.
column17: Provide a descriptor if an anatomical part was sampled. Use the picklist provided in the template. If a desired term is missing from the picklist, contact emma_griffiths@sfu.ca. If not applicable, do not leave blank. Choose a null value.

column16: A substance excreted/secreted from an organism e.g. feces, urine, sweat.
column17: Provide a descriptor if a body product was sampled. Use the picklist provided in the template.  If a desired term is missing from the picklist, contact emma_griffiths@sfu.ca. If not applicable, do not leave blank. Choose a null value.

column16: A substance obtained from the natural or man-made environment e.g. soil, water, sewage.
column17: Provide a descriptor if an environmental material was sampled. Use the picklist provided in the template.  If a desired term is missing from the picklist, contact emma_griffiths@sfu.ca. If not applicable, do not leave blank. Choose a null value.

column16: An environmental location may describe a site in the natural or built environment e.g. contact surface, metal can, hospital, wet market, bat cave.
column17: Provide a descriptor if an environmental site was sampled. Use the picklist provided in the template.  If a desired term is missing from the picklist, contact emma_griffiths@sfu.ca. If not applicable, do not leave blank. Choose a null value.

column16: The instrument or container used to collect the sample e.g. swab.
column17: Provide a descriptor if a device was used for sampling. Use the picklist provided in the template. If a desired term is missing from the picklist, contact emma_griffiths@sfu.ca. If not applicable, do not leave blank. Choose a null value.

column16: The process used to collect the sample e.g. phlebotamy, necropsy.
column17: Provide a descriptor if a collection method was used for sampling. Use the picklist provided in the template.  If a desired term is missing from the picklist, contact emma_griffiths@sfu.ca. If not applicable, do not leave blank. Choose a null value.

column16: The name and version of a particular protocol used for sampling.
column17: Free text.

column16: Any processing applied to the sample during or after receiving the sample.
column17: Critical for interpreting data. Select all the applicable processes from the pick list. If virus was passaged, include information in "lab host", "passage number", and "passage method" fields. If none of the processes in the pick list apply, put "not applicable".

column16: Detailed information regarding the processing applied to a sample during or after receiving the sample.
column17: Provide a free text description of any processing details applied to a sample.
column18: 25 swabs were pooled and further prepared as a single sample during library prep.

column16: The strain identifier.
column17: If the isolate represents or is derived from, a lab reference strain or strain from a type culture collection, provide the strain identifier.

column16: The type of planned process by which an organismal entity is associated with a taxon or taxa.
column17: Provide the type of method used to determine the taxonomic identity of the organism by selecting a value from the pick list. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The details of the process used to determine the taxonomic identification of an organism.
column17: Provide the criteria used for 16S sequencing taxonomic determination by selection a value from the pick list. These criteria are specific to the AMBR project and so not ontologized. The pick list is strictly for providing consistency in records rather than implementing community data standards.  If another method was used for the taxonomic determination, leave blank.
column18: Species-level ID: >99.3% identity and unambiguous match to one type (T) sequence in a curated database

column16: An environmental datum specifying the temperature at which an organism or organisms were incubated for the purposes of growth on or in a particular medium.
column17: Provide the temperature at which the isolate was isolated.

column16: An environmental datum specifying the temperature unit at which an organism or organisms were incubated for the purposes of growth on or in a particular medium.
column17: Select the temperature unit from the pick list.

column16: An isolation medium is a culture medium which has the disposition to encourage growth of particular bacteria to the exclusion of others in the same growth environment.
column17: Select the isolation medium from the pick list.

column16: An isolate datum specifying the location of where an isolate is stored e.g. in a particular freezer, on a particular shelf
column17: Enter the freezer storage location of the isolate as the "freezer number-shelf number-box number-unit number" e.g. FR1-R3-B1-S01.

column16: An isolate datum specifying the type of cellular respiration process used by the organism.
column17: Select the respiration type from the pick list.

column16: The commonly used name of the host.
column17: Common name or scientific name are required if there was a host. Both can be provided, if known. Use terms from the pick lists in the template. Common name e.g. human, bat. If the sample was environmental, put "not applicable.

column16: The taxonomic, or scientific name of the host.
column17: Common name or scientific name are required if there was a host. Both can be provided, if known. Use terms from the pick lists in the template. Scientific name e.g. Homo sapiens, If the sample was environmental, put "not applicable

column16: The name of the disease experienced by the host.
column17: Select "COVID-19" from the pick list provided in the template.

column16: The name of the agency, organization or institution responsible for sequencing the isolate's genome.
column17: Provide the name of the agency, organization or institution that performed the sequencing in full (avoid abbreviations). If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The specific laboratory affiliation of the responsible for sequencing the isolate's genome.
column17: Provide the name of the specific laboratory that that performed the sequencing in full (avoid abbreviations). If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The name or title of the contact responsible for follow-up regarding the sequence.
column17: Provide the name of an individual or their job title. As personnel turnover may render the contact's name obsolete, it is more prefereable to provide a job title for ensuring accuracy of information and institutional memory. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The email address of the contact responsible for follow-up regarding the sequence.
column17: Provide the email associated with the listed contact. As personnel turnover may render an individual's email obsolete, it is more prefereable to provide an address for a position or lab, to ensure accuracy of information and institutional memory. If the information is unknown or cannot be provided, leave blank or provide a null value.

column16: The reason that the sample was sequenced.
column17: The reason why a sample was originally collected may differ from the reason why it was selected for sequencing. The reason a sample was sequenced may provide information about potential biases in sequencing strategy. Provide the purpose of sequencing from the picklist in the template. The reason for sample collection should be indicated in the "purpose of sampling" field.

column16: The description of why the sample was sequenced providing specific details.
column17: Provide an expanded description of why the sample was sequenced using free text. The description may include the importance of the sequences for a particular public health investigation/surveillance activity/research question. Suggested standardized descriotions include: Screened for S gene target failure (S dropout), Screened for mink variants, Screened for B.1.1.7 variant, Screened for B.1.135 variant, Screened for P.1 variant, Screened due to travel history, Screened due to close contact with infected individual, Assessing public health control measures, Determining early introductions and spread, Investigating airline-related exposures, Investigating temporary foreign worker, Investigating remote regions, Investigating health care workers, Investigating schools/universities, Investigating reinfection.
column18: Screened for S gene target failure (S dropout)

column16: The date the sample was sequenced.
column17: ISO 8601 standard "YYYY-MM-DD".

column16: The user-specified identifier for the library prepared for sequencing.
column17: Provide the "Sequencing Batch #" information in the field.

column16: The model of the sequencing instrument used.
column17: Select a sequencing instrument from the picklist provided in the template.

column16: The name and version number of the sequencing protocol used.
column17: Provide the name and version of the sequencing protocol e.g. 1D_DNA_MinION

column16: The protocol used to generate the sequence.
column17: Provide a free text description of the methods and materials used to generate the sequence. Suggested text, fill in information where indicated.: "Viral sequencing was performed following a tiling amplicon strategy using the <fill in> primer scheme. Sequencing was performed using a <fill in> sequencing instrument. Libraries were prepared using <fill in> library kit. "
column18: Genomes were generated through amplicon sequencing of 1200 bp amplicons with Freed schema primers. Libraries were created using Illumina DNA Prep kits, and sequence data was produced using Miseq Micro v2 (500 cycles) sequencing kits.

column16: An information content entity specifying a list of primers used for amplicon sequencing.
column17: Select the primers used to generate the 16S amplicon for sequencing from the pick list. The primers should be separated in the list using semicolons.

column16: The name of the file containing the sequence data to be analysed.
column17: Enter the file name of the gene sequence.

column16: An identifier that specifies an individual sequence record in a public sequence repository.
column17: Enter the EZBioCloud gene accession thatmost closely matches the sequence being analyzed.

column16: A description of the overall bioinformatics strategy used.
column17: Further details regarding the methods used to process raw data, and/or generate assemblies, and/or generate consensus sequences can. This information can be provided in an SOP or protocol or pipeline/workflow. Provide the name and version number of the protocol, or a GitHub link to a pipeline or workflow.

column16: An identifier of a biological or bioinformatics database.
column17: Select the reference database name from the pick list.

column16: The version of the database containing the reference sequences used for analysis.
column17: Enter the sequence search date as the version of EZBioCloud used. Record the date in ISO 8601 format i.e. YYYY_MM_DD.

column16: The percentage of the reference sequence covered by the sequence of interest.
column17: Enter the completeness value. Do not include any symbols e.g. %.

column16: Sequence identity is the number (%) of matches (identical characters) in positions from an alignment of two molecular sequences.
column17: Enter the identity value. Do not include any symbols e.g. %.

column16: The ratio of the reference sequence not covered by the sequence of interest.
The taxon derived from the top hit in search results produced from a sequence similarity comparison.
column17: Enter the EZBioCloud taxon best-hit.

column16: The strain designation derived from the top hit in search results produced from a sequence similarity comparison.
column17: Enter the EZBioCloud strain best-hit.

column16: The results of a data transformation of sequence data in which (e.g., low quality) read bases are removed to produce a trimmed ribosomal RNA sequence.
column17: Enter the sequence of the trimmed ribosomal gene sequence.

column16: Any notes regarding the bioinformatics analysis.
column17: Enter any notes regarding the analysis as free text.

column16: Names of individuals contributing to the processes of sample collection, sequence generation, analysis, and data submission.
column17: Include the first and last names of all individuals that should be attributed, separated by a comma.
column18: Tejinder Singh, Fei Hu, Joe Blogs

column16: The DataHarmonizer software and template version provenance.
column17: The current software and template version information will be automatically generated in this field after the user utilizes the "validate" function. This information will be generated regardless as to whether the row is valid of not.
